reviewText:
This RPG game is a nice change up from storming castles and dungeon crawlers.  Takes place in unique settings from planes, to trains, and city streets for example.  The goal is to rescue the girlfriend, after doing that the goal is to rescue whoever else is kidnapped by the bad guys.  Lots of party members to choose from makes each playthrough feel new.  Levels all have unique monsters that fit the level.  There are unlockable characters by beating different modes in different ways.  With the levels just the right size this game is great to speedrun, even better on higher difficulties where the characters move speed becomes super fast!  Great replay value!

There is no manual for the game that explains ANYTHING in the game or what skills do, or describes any of the stats.  Apparently some of that info is in a separate guide players can buy somewhere online, but even that doesnt include the details of what party members do what people say.  Only way to find a good party is to experiment around and see what works best, or just charge in blindly!   There is also no way to play full screen, hitting alt enter leaves those annoying black bars on every side meaning 30-40% of the screen is just black.  Its un noticable as the heat of battle kicks in though.  WIthout a manual its not a perfect 10 but its so close otherwise from great music to great replay value its a fun RPG to kill time with and change things up from the usual.

Rating:  8/10  Value:  $4.99

reviewText:
Girlfriend Rescue is perhaps one of the dumbest and most simple RPGs ever. It has nothing particularly special about it – it's made with RPG Maker, the story is laughably silly, and the gameplay is pretty much what you'd expect from a typical turn-based RPG. So, why am I recommending it? Well, read on and find out!

The BreakdownThe game “combines the atmosphere of Streets of Rage with the gameplay of Dragon Quest”, according to the store page at least. The gameplay might be a little different than Dragon Quest, but the bit about Streets of Rage is pretty much spot on – this is clearly a silly game with a silly premise. I mean, the name says it all!

Perhaps one of the funniest parts about the story though is that the girl you're trying to rescue from the bad guys (ninjas, of course!) isn't actually the main character's girlfriend. Instead, she's just some random girl that the guy has a crush on. He decides to team up with 3 of 13 (4 of those are unlockables)  characters/friends to stop the bad guys. Personally, I found the character designs for the party members to be pretty amusing. My party consisted of the main dude, a shady-looking “dealer” character, a little boy, and a frog. Yep, a frog. Each of the characters have amusing dialogue occasionally, yet what truly sets them apart from each other is their strategies during battles.

See, the gameplay of Girlfriend Rescue basically consists of a series of battles in a set area. The game throws you into a series of areas linked together by an overall location (like say, a line of train cars in a train). In these, you fight a variety of enemies, collect items by walking into objects (yeah, it's weird), and manage your party through equipping gear or using consumables like pizza, drugs, or “red toro” (Red Bull). The battles themselves are pretty much what you'd expect: turn-based attacks, skills, defending, and whatnot. Each character has their own special skills (sometimes with silly names) that sometimes apply status effects to enemies; certain weapons can also do this.

Now, a somewhat minor complaint I had is that it was a bit difficult to remember what most of these status effects actually do. There's a LOT of them – quite a bit more than most RPGs – and it became tough to try and remember what would happen if an enemy “infected” one of my party members, made them “tired”, “doomed”, etc. There's police officers NPCs that can be found every once in a while and explain about a few status effects, but it would be nice to have a help section or even just an item that gives little text blurbs about each status effect as a quick refesher.

Another part that bugged me about Girlfriend Rescue was how repetitive it got after a while. Each “world” was basically the exact same – slap on a fresh new coat of paint for the scenery and enemies, fight a bunch of enemies in a mostly linear path, then rinse and repeat. There wasn't a lot of variety besides the pixel art, different songs for different worlds, enemy designs, and bosses. Speaking of bosses, they were pretty much incredibly easy, or at least all the ones that I fought were. I would have gotten farther, but.....well......

….the difficulty. This game has really strange difficulty spikes. At the beginning of the game, it recommends you play on Easy for a first playthrough, which I found a bit odd, so I decided to be rebellious and pick Normal. Now, for most of the game I had a good challenge, but it was nothing too tough. For the first few worlds, my characters rarely died at all. Yet, when I reached the 4th world, I kept dying to the enemies of that area, zombies. It wasn't too much, but it was definitely a noticeable difference in difficulty from the previous areas. The weird part though is that the 5th area was one of the easiest for me – I beat the boss (or rather 2 bosses) quite quickly and the enemies were similarly a breeze. However, the 6th location......oh jeez. It began simple enough: a town with snakes. So what? Well, it turned out to be extremely difficult, to the point that my characters were all either dying or nearly dying after every battle. Those damn snakes were crazy hard, and the weird part is that the difficulty spike sort of came out of nowhere – I had great equipment and a decent combo of powerful fighters and spell casters at that point. So, I don't really understand why that area was so incredibly challenging for pretty much no reason. Eh, oh well.

Anyway, why might I be recommending this game then? To be honest, I think a lot of it was how charming I found the game to be. The story made me laugh at its silliness, and pretty much everything about the game was dumb. Yet, the game embraced its stupidity and just sort of went with it. I love it for that. Yeah, it's clearly not amazing – the repetitive nature of the gameplay limits it quite a bit. For a silly little RPG Maker game though? Not bad, not bad at all!

reviewText:
Girlfriend rescue is an old school RPG with some interesting elements. The story is, well in the title, your girlfriend gets kidnapped and you go and rescue her. Totally not a cliche. The game is funny too. The story line was good in my opinion


Graphics and sound:

It’s standard RPGmaker graphics and sound are okay.

Gameplay:

It’s an okay RPG for it’s price, if you have 5-6 hours and nothing to do, go ahead and play this game. Replay value is good as you can always choose different difficulty settings or different party members. When you start the game you get a choice to make your party with different skills/stats characters you can have many combinations.

Conclusion:

A decent RPG with a good story and theme. Cheap as well so go ahead and buy if you’re a classic RPG games fan.

reviewText:
Edit:  I am adding/removing things as I'm going through.  As a result, I don't consider this to be a full review.

It's possible that my review will change as I progress further into the game, but so far I'm not impressed.  Before I continue, a little about me.  I've been working with different versions of RPG Maker since the late 90s.  In fact, even now I'm working on an RPG Maker VX title that I will hopefully submit on Steam at some point, though that is easily months away from now.  That said, I have a number of issues with this title.

Almost everything reeks of generic.  The main character is not interesting, nor are any of the side characters.  The dialogue really needs to be entirely redone as it's very amateurish and riddled with multiple grammatical errors that I would overlook if they were attempting to parody other grammatical errors from other games, but clearly they are not.  There are a lot of subtle issues with the game as well.

For starters, barely pressing in one direction in a menu will often cause my cursor to go crazy and skip several lines or just straight up go into hyperdrive.  This has caused me to run from battles where I meant to go into rush instead.  While the graphics are entirely custom, the characters and environments are pretty terrible and low res in general, which makes the game feel that even further cheapened.

I mean, I get it...the sheer number of normal Steam users that complain and drone on about default RTP for RPG Maker more or less forces you to use custom everything and that's fine, but at least make it something halfway appealing and BETTER than the default.  It also doesn't help that certain things went unchecked.  For example, when you stumble upon a merchant, you have the option to deal or not.  If you select not to, it still brings up the shop menu.

These are things that should have been ironed out WAY before release.  As I said, it's possible that I will enjoy it more as time goes on (the opening cutscene was pretty nice for example), but as it stands this comes off more bland and unappealing than I had anticipated.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Girlfriend Rescue is a turn/round-based RPG through and through which starts out with a conversation among friends about approaching your crush, but you find out that some recently escaped prisoner has taken her!  You have to form a party to find a way to save her.  You start out with choices you can make about your gender, name, crush’s name, and once you can move around, you have a selection of up to two other members you are friendly with that can help you out as you start your quest to get your girl back.  I would have liked to have been able to try them all to find out what each possible party member could do, but I would not really know future abilities as they leveled up anyway, so it is probably not a very important issue.

As you begin, you get a lot of nice tips from the local police NPCs on various aspects of play.  This was helpful for me as I began journeying around.  There are a lot of various original things about this RPG game that I like, such as the various debuffs and what can change when things happen.  They are atypical to what I am used to seeing, which is pretty interesting and refreshing to me.  I mean, a lot of it involves various stats, so it’s not too different, but the way it is done is not the typical type of stuff.  I like what I’ve encountered so far in this game.  The combat system is a standard turn-based style where you have attack and defend commands along with special moves you can learn as you level up, which you pick for the next round, and watch the round unfold.

The actual gameplay outside of combat is roaming around a map, trying to find X amount of enemies on the area you explore, and taking out the last guy on the map.  I have not tried finishing an area with less than the target number, but I am guessing your bonus reward at the end would change if you got less than the number it shows, which finalizes after the last “boss” character on the map, as far as I can tell, ever since the first area I explored fully.


Pros
The plot is different, and I find the initial gameplay and overall setting nicely done.

The look of the areas so far work with what’s going on at the paticular time.  Fits in nicely.

Since you can only pick limited characters for each run through the game, there is some replay value with this to find out what other characters are about, and which combinations might work the best on a harder difficulty, for instance.  I haven’t finished to see if there is a new game plus, and what that entails exactly, but there is definitely some replay value here in some way shape or form, which I always like!

I am always happy when I can be rewarded with items for exploring around.  Most stuff seems to be added to inventory automatically when you are on the proper square or area, so it makes it a bit easier not having to mindlessly press buttons to click each spot.  Some boxes do require a click, but they are usually obvious.

The various combat mechanics in the special moves are very different than the standard RPG type of moves.  I really like the originality that is put into many of my party’s special techniques.

The status effects are not standard to RPGs either, and the originality is nice to see.  While most just lower stats in a few areas or stop you from moving, etc. they are not your typical “paralyze” or whatever.  Some will have a chance to go away after a turn or so, while others can last a bit longer.  They have interesting debuff names and the debuffs are generally not the typical types of effects.  Usually seems to be a series of stats that are lowered for most I have encountered so far.  Some will persist until you cure it, like hunger for instance.  There are a good many battle stat debuffs, and they have various different things they change or lower on your characters.

By clearing areas and dispatching every enemy there, you gain a special bonus, which carries over to the next areas.  You also get several items, which I haven’t tried comparing yet to unfinished area bonuses.

Autosaves after five battles have gone by.

While it doesn’t affect things too terribly much, the hunger aspect lowers stats a bit in certain areas.  I like the addition of needing to eat as you travel.


Cons
Very linear gameplay.  While I don’t expect anything like a total open world experience, I would like more choice, and the possibility of returning enemies to grind if I wanted to do so.  One aspect I enjoy on RPGs that I miss here.

If I level up with items, I am unable to see what improves.  I can only see this directly when I win battles and level up.

Some of the items are not very clear as to what they do, or are buggy.  Some don’t seem to work the way they should.  The Red Toro is supposed to counter Tired status, but it remains on the alien I try to use it on, but works on other characters.  Another character was Infected, and Cortisol never works for removal of this.  It might only work when actually in battle, but I haven’t really tried and compared this to being out of battle, where it doesn’t change the status effect while on characters.

Near the beginning, when I am first able to choose my party, it would be nice to be able to see what each one is capable of.  Maybe being able to switch out at various times if I wanted to just try others instead of needing to start over and try them a while.  Of course, with no grinding, this would probably not be advantageous unless they took the same level as the character they were switched out for, since you wouldn’t get as many experience points for the three you would mainly use, and they would be spread out too much, which would cause an imbalance in the parity that exists in a limited battle grind-free style environment..

I love a good map, even on something I consider a bit linear.  Good to know where I am.


ConclusionIs the game worth the $4.99 USD price tag to pick up?  Probably.  I think with the replay value, and the decent length of the game so far among other things, that alone is worth it.  The combat has some interesting abilities and the buffs and debuffs are not your ordinary stuff, for the most part.  I’m the type that likes to get games on sale, so I’d pick it up on a deal, but saying that, this game is definitely worth the price it is at, and I am surprised it does not carry a higher base price, honestly.  It’s a good one for the RPGMaker style engine.  I can highly recommend this game after my fairly limited gameplay thus far.

reviewText:
Fast-paced, challenging, with great replay value
Choose three gang members and save your girl. Sounds simple? It is - but the value of GR lies in its complexity and variability.
There are multiple levels - streets,  secret labs, train, etc. Each of these levels feels unique, with different looks, enemies and music themes. For completing a level, you receive a reward in a form of bonus (more damage for certain weapons, better healing and so on). The better the level completition, the better the reward. Once earned bonuses carry into new games, so it's a good idea to play GR more than once.

The battles are turn-based and require lot of different strategies. Sometimes the enemies can be paralyzed or poisoned, sometimes brute force is the best solution. Some spells are also placement-based (hit enemies on the left), so enemies positions matter, too.
Resources are limited, both supplies and enemies, so you can't over-level" the game. And healing is very costly
date: plus you don't get the best bonuses if you use it. Depending on bonuses
hoursPlayed: you regenerate a bit of health (and "magic") after each successful fight. Similarly as in Dreamscape
voteText: it makes the right party composition and strategy  crucial.\nEasy difficulty is good for testing the characters and viable parties
helpfulPercent: because Normal and Hard are simply not doable with "wrong" party. And the harder modes (unlocked by fully completing Hard) are only possible with multiple bonuses. GR is definitively a challenging game.\n\nThe levels are relatively straightforwards - no sidequests
votesHelpful: no "turning-back" (i.e. you can't return to a level once you completed it)
votesTotal: but there are still many well-hidden items and you usually discover something new in each playthrough. Overall
votesFunny: I enjoyed the complexity of the game. There are just so many party and bonuses combinations. And each of these influences your playing style. And thanks to its fast-pace
commentsCount: it feels pretty addictive. There's certainly the "complete one last level" feeling to it. And after completing all the levels
column16: it's "do it better and on higher difficulty."\nOn top of it
column20: ...) felt pretty refreshing from the usual "Dragons and Elves" thing. GR is a must in my book."

reviewText:
Product received for free

This review is created for  Deduction's Review Club .   I received this game for free, however, my review is unbiased

There is also a video counterpart to this review, which I highly recommend you check out.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JjJueu0yUOo
Anyway, onto the review. Girlfriend Rescue was developed by Aldorlea Games, was released on July 10th 2015 Girlfriend rescue is an indie RPG, which describes itself as a cross between Dragon Quest and Streets of Rage, however, my experience with the game feels more like diluted gameplay of Final Fantasy mixed with the urban setting of Streets of Rage. Girlfriend Rescue is an RPGMaker game, and those familiar with RPG Maker games know that they are not always the highest quality of games, for obvious reasons. Girlfriend Rescue is not an exception, however, compared to some of the other RPGMaker games I have played in the past, I quite enjoyed Girlfriend Maker.

The story to Girlfriend Rescue is about how the love of your life is kidnapped by a crime syndicate, and it’s up to you, and your friends, to save her.

The gameplay is my favorite part of the game. The combat is very enjoyable, and for casual RPG players, or those looking to spark an interest in the JRPG, or perhaps even seasoned JRPG enthusiasts looking for something a bit easier to play or to 100% achieve the achievements. Those looking for replay value Should not turn away from Girlfriend Rescue, since every playthrough you can choose A different party of characters, or equip different items and utilities.

The graphics for Girlfriend Rescue aren’t the greatest, however, they are decent and not too hard on the eyes. There are many hand drawn scenes in Girlfriend Rescue which are very visually pleasing. However, like every game, there are cons. One downside to Girlfriend Rescue which I Immediately noticed was the music.

The soundtrack to the game is composed solely of creative commons music. Now, you might be thinking, “Hey Deviation! You use NoCopyrightSounds in your videos, how does that make you any better?” Well, the simple truth is, I don’t make anyone pay to watch my videos, however, to play Girlfriend Rescue, you’re going to have to fork over some of your hard earned money.

Another downside to Girlfriend Rescue is the illusion of choice at the very beginning. Similar to Pokemon Mystery Dungeon: Red Rescue Team, although there are probably a lot more games that have the same beginning, Girlfriend Rescue will ask you a few questions. What’s your name, what sexuality are you, what gender, and if you have a crush or whatever you want to call it. However, after answering all of those questions, it does not have an outcome on your game. For example, me, being the funny guy I am, chose the option that I’m gay at the beginning of the game  (but I’m not in real life if you're wondering) , however, it still said that I was in love with the damsel in distress (Laura). I’m pretty sure that those who are homosexual only like those of the same gender, and since I was a male and homosexual, doesn’t that mean I’m only attracted to men? Yeah, I thought so. Check mate, game.

The final downside to the game is the odd theme. The first few levels make since, you're in an urban setting fighting off thugs and rats, however, as soon as you go into a very modern apartment building, you’re greeted by ninjas, samurai, and other Oriental themed enemies. Very strange, but not a huge downside. However, if you are a fan of old school JRPGs with an odd story, or if you are interested in indie games in general, I would recommend Girlfriend Rescue, however strange it may be, however, I would suggest you mute the audio and play whatever music you like, as I did.

Rating:
Graphics: 7.2/10
Audio: 3/10
Gameplay: 7.6/10
Overall: 5.9/10

Enjoy the review? Please check out  Deduction's Review Club  as well as my  YouTube Channel .

reviewText:
This game made by RPGMaker and have a classical Beat ’em up story plot, but now we don't in a fantasy world what we can see in a lot of that style game, we are in the modern Detroit city. Story is that: Bad guys are kidnapped your girlfriend and you decided bring her back with your friends. The story and the music enough good in the game. Gameplay also enjoyable, at the start you have a lot of choice from a lot of companions what you should pick to your journey, are they have different skills, so this bring a good replay value to the game. Game have a world with a lot of hidden items what you can found and have achievements.

So my verdict

+good music
+lot of characters
+achievements
+trading cards
+good replay value
+some different difficulty level
+enough good base price

-not everyone like that style

SO i think this game enough good, if you like this style and like do achievements, its game for you. Price is enough fair, but if this game be in bundle, this can be must buy category.

7.5/10

reviewText:
I think I've put in enough time to get a feel for this game.

Pros:

-Good music for an RPG maker title
-Some of the character design is nice
-Can be pretty difficult, that could go either way, depends on if you like a challenge
-Has Achievements
-Has Trading cards

Cons:

-Right off the bat, I noticed that the controls can't be modified, and the default movement is not the D-pad... why? I feel like precise movements should be the thing here.
-Story is... lackluster, though I only made it to chapter 2, but I didn't feel like it was going anywhere suprising... though I did see a zombie screenshot on the store page. Wish I could have made it to that part.
-Some of the items and dialog are good, but some of the item labels make no sense. I'm thinking this might be a translation issue.
-I played on easy mode and got killed a lot in chapter 2, maybe its because I didn't grind enough, maybe I didn't pick the right team, but it feel too difficult to continue.
-Sometimes, squares will be present in the dialog or item descriptions, like a character is missing. Not sure what that's about.
-This game has been out for over a year and these problems still exist, which leads me to belive that they will never be fixed.

Overall, I'd give the game a 5/10. Just barely recommended.

I wouldn't pay full price for it but it'll kill a few hours. It seems deep... if you really fell into it, it'd last you a long time, but it just didn't grip me.

*Disclaimer: I was provided with a free copy of this game by the developer in order to review it.

reviewText:
Recently finished, so here's my 2 cents:

Girlfriend Rescue is your standard issue RPG Maker game, both developed and published by Aldorlea Games (notorious developer of many RPG Maker games). Its a JRPG that handles similar to old school Dragon Warrior or Final Fantasy, but with a bit more room for strategy in both building your party and combat. The story itself takes place in a modern, urban setting which is a breath of fresh air (ironically) as opposed to your typical medieval fantasies. There's an interesting variety of characters to construct your party with, to which you will use to trudge through the 8 different scenarios. Explore a bit, loot things, fight baddies, and continue onwards. At the end of each scenario you get a little piece of story that serves as a reminder in case you forgot what the game was all about (see: title), and then you go back to walking and mashing the X button.

Its not the most fun I've had with one of these kinds of games, in fact I'm a bit disappointed in Aldorlea Games. After playing Deadly Sin 2 and Skyborn, I really expected more from this title. I only recommend it if you have absolutely no other RPGs to play.. or just really need that old school RPG fix, even then wait for a sale.

Pros:

+ Interesting variety of characters
+ Fresh, urban setting
+ Fast paced combat
+ Colorful visuals

Cons:

- Mediocre story
- Poorly written dialogue
- Repetitive battles
- Ugly enemy artwork
- Vague character/skill descriptions
- Messed up controls with my X360 gamepad
- Lack of settings (volume, controls, etc)

5/10

reviewText: I would like to start of by saying that I am usually a big fan of Aldorlea games, especially the Laxius Force and Millennium series, but I honestly did not like this game.\nIt reminds me more of a dungeon crawler game, as all you really have to do in each world is kill all the enemies and find your way out. There are no sidequests (which is one of the best parts of rpgs in my opinion), and while the fact that you can play as a gay or straight guy or girl is great, the story really didn't grab my attention.

reviewText: This is a flawed game, that said, it's also pretty fun. The battling in this game can get tedious, and the writing isn't particularly good, but those problems aren't so problematic that they ruin the experience. In my playthorugh I have enjoyed myself fighting the varied enemies, using the skills unique to each character, searching items for loot, and customizing my character's gear. The two biggest problems I have with the game is that combat grows repeteitive and boring if you play for more than an hour or two, and the fact that regardless of whether you put down your gender as male, female, gay or straight, you are always playing as a male character trying to save a woman, since the main character has no personality beyond wanting to save a the girl  (yeah, she's not actually your girlfirend yet, despite the name of the game)  I don't understand why your can't play as a female trying to rescue a man, or a homosexual female, or a male trying to rescue a male, all that it would have required was a skin change for the main character and a couple of alternate pieces of still art, if there was any animation or voice acting in the game then I would understand, but there isn't and the game asks you your gender and sexual preference at the beggining so I don't understand this decision. And as I mentioned, the main character has almost literally no personality, though the supporting party members make up for that somewhat, they actually have personalities, though those are all hilariously one dimensional. In the party from my playthough, I had a guy who kept on talking about working out, a girl who kept talking about cosplay, and a different guy who only ever talked about his informants." there is something kind of funny about these characters

reviewText:
GR is a fun RPG set in the present day instead of the usual (and a bit worn out) fantasy settings. It has a lot of characters that you can pick from the beginning and because of that you will certainly want to experiment different parties to find the best. Another thing I can recommend is to check all the barrels, crates and even bins for items. Good stuff to collect.

So it's certainly not the best game by this developer but it is one that shows effort and has among the best collection of artworks by them. Your girlfriend in particular is gorgeous and definitely gave me an incentive to go after her (in Easy mode because I'm not demented, in love maybe but demented I'm not)

reviewText:
Product received for free

SHORT VERSION

8/10

+ Skills
+ music
+ finding items without pressing action key

+ linear stages

- Healing items.

LONG VERSION

When I first saw this game, I was a bit doubtful; story didn't interest me too much and I used to play medieval/fantasy or sci-fi rpgs and this was (kinda) present time in normal world. But I decided give it a try, and glad I did that! Game was hilarious and I kept laughing thro playtime. (It could had something to do late hours I played tho) Character's classes were silly and their skills were ridiculous, suited users perfectly.

And overall, I enjoyed this game, more than I thought I would.  It was very linear, different from most games I've played, not much room to exploring (and getting lost) but its fine once in a while. Game also was challenging at some parts, due no item-, money- or levelgrinding and NPC heals weren't available so often. And you couldn't save when you wanted, if you didn't feel like backtracking a lot. I got couple close-calls, and one wipe at boss fights (Just one more hit

reviewText:
There is a lot of fun to be had in Girlfriend Rescue, a game that is more complex than it looks. Beginning with your party selection and continuing with the battle strategies, this is a different type of adventure that will keep you busy for a good while:
- lots of replay via the character selections and difficulty levels.
- artwork is very good.
- lots of things to find as you explore the levels.
- present day story is different, but still a good time.
So give this one a try and you will be drawn in pretty quickly to a unique rpg experience.

reviewText:
I usually like Aldorlea's output, and was impressed by The Book Of Legends, but this time they brought a game that is mediocre right from the uninspired name.
Streets of Rage and similar brawlers have nothing to do with it, this is just your average RPG with pills and drugs instead of potions and magic. As for the “real world” setting, the contrived yet paper-thin plot gives several excuses to throw among enemies random stuff like zombies, medieval knights and Taoist monks just to recycle sprites presumably from other titles.
The combat itself quickly becomes a chore and most of the levels are particularly uninspired and repetitive (especially areas 4 & 5), with lame graphics and no different things to do other than fight. The characters are not interesting at all, and the writing is amusing in places, but substitutes the wittiness and charm from TBOL with slang and memes that quickly get old.
I don't recommend buying this at full price, and even then just if you're a JRPG fanatic.

reviewText:
I really don't like giving any video game thumbs down...but this is just not good. You spawn in a city and choose players, then you just go. No explanation. You just go. Battles in the first level (yes, I said level, there's no world to explore) of this game are just too easy. The lack of difficulty just made me not want to play this.

And I realize not every RPG has to be super difficult like Dark Souls or that oldschool roguelike NetHack, but there should at least be some element of challenge to motivate me.

There are no random encounters. Some people really like this, but I'd prefer the surprise, which adds to the challenge in certain ways. The enemies just seem ridiculously stupid and thrown together.

Now, graphics. Yes, I realize this is an RPGMaker game. I repeat: I REALIZE THIS IS AN RPGMAKER GAME. But the graphics are just bad even for an RPGMaker game. A few more colorful sprites or tiles would help me appreciate this more.

Now, I'm not saying this is complete trash. I guess the aspect of hidden items gets people to explore. But there's not enough for me to want to explore. Plus a lot of the hidden items are the same.

Maybe I'll go back to this game if I don't have anything else to do. But I just don't see the appeal now that I've played it, even though it caught my eye so long ago.
